results.title: Sand casting: an art adventure
results.creator_credit: Bill Mackie, Easy Street Productions and Centron Films
results.brief_description: Shows a young woman and several children making sand casts of several objects. The adult demonstrator shows the step by step procedure for making and decorating plaster of paris castings using inexpensive materials. Suitable for upper primary level.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bill Mackie, Easy Street Productions and Centron Films

results.title: Sand and flame
results.brief_description: Open with a survey of the development of glass-making and the art of the early glass-blower. Shows manufacture of wide range of glass products, including the automatic bottle-making process; manufacture of fine glass tubing; transformation of glass marbles into glass fibre; production of glass bricks; furnacing, rolling, cutting, grinding and polishing of plate glass; manufacture of shatter-proof plate glass.

results.title: San Junipero
results.brief_description: When Yorkie and Kelly visit San Junipero, a fun-loving beach town full of surf, sun and sex, their lives are changed in this acclaimed episode of Black Mirror.

constellations_other.name: VR dreams
constellations_other.description: Since VR's inception creators have explored the ways VR could be used to enhance our lives and even extend them.

results.title: San Francisco; Hollywood; Beverly Hills
results.brief_description: Hang ten at Huntington Beach or take a ski run at Big Bear. Discover history preserved in landmarks and revel in world renowned performing arts. See the vast variety of California’s lifestyle cities. Explore the hills and valleys of San Francisco: ride a trolley car, explore the Barbary Coast, enjoy museums, opera, symphony and distinguished cuisine on Fisherman’s Wharf. Travel to the bustling mega-tropolis Los Angeles and tour the infamous Beverly Hills and Hollywood, home to the rich and famous. Marvel at the sites and sounds of southern California - at the regions natural beauty from beaches to desert to snow-capped mountains. All without leaving your own lounge chair!

results.title: San Francisco: city at the end of the rainbow
results.brief_description: This travelogue takes the viewer on a tour of San Francisco to discover the curious and unusual facets of the city. Among the many attractions of San Francisco is a cable car ride to Fisherman’s Wharf, Alcatraz, one of the city’s most eeriest attractions, the Columbus Day Parade and the fascinating spectacle of fog rolling in over the city. Take a trip along the Golden Gate Bridge and never leave your armchair.

results.title: San Francisco Bay Area Rapid Transit: conflict with Berkeley
results.brief_description: The basis of the conflict between BART (Bay Area Rapid Transport) and the Berkley Community was whether tracks, for a kind of railway, should be placed over or under ground. The mayor of the time and some other people explain how the fight was conducted and the strategies of BART and Berkeley and the final victory for Berkeley.

results.title: San Francisco
results.creator_credit: W S. Van Dyke, Bernard H. Hyman, John Emerson and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: A lavish production set in San Francisco, in which Clark Gable plays the role of Blackie Norton, proprietor of a riotous saloon. When Jeanette MacDonald arrives on the scene in search of a singing career, they fall in love. The climax takes place amongst the recreation of the great earthquake that hit the city in 1906. Cast also includes Spencer Tracy, Jack Holt, Jessie Ralph and Ted Healy. Screenplay by Anita Loos from the story by Robert Hopkins. Edited by Tom Neld.

results.title: San Andreas fault
results.creator_credit: Bert Van Bork, American Geological Institute and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Presents evidence of geological forces at work relating to the causes of earthquakes. Describes the scientific methods used to study current seismic activity in the San Andreas Fault in California.

results.title: Samurai Warrior: The Battles of Usagi Yojimbo  for ZX Spectrum
results.material_description: Cassette tape computer game. Cassette, cover & manual insert in clear plastic cassette case
results.brief_description:
“Samurai Warrior: The Battles of Usagi Yojimbo” is based on a successful comic book by Stan Sakai. The hero is an anthropomorphic rabbit named Miyamoto Usagi, living in seventeenth-century Japan. Usagi is a masterless samurai (a ronin), who wanders the land, occasionally taking up work as a bodyguard.

In this game, you play as Usagi, who sword fights his opponents, bandits and ninja, who often disguise themselves as harmless villagers or priests. The aim of the game is for Usagi to rescue Lord Noriyuki, a panda who has been captured by Lord Hikiji.

The scenery beautifully detailed, and the game presents sideways scrolling action, with Usagi’s movements on the right of the screen, and the left dedicated to status information. The landscape forms an important is part of the game, with creatures lurking behind rocks or up trees. There are also rivers and chasms, which require skill to jump over safely.

The scoring system is based on karma points: good deeds increase Usagi’s karma points, while bad deeds decrease it. Each interaction with other characters must be considered in relation to karma. A larger portrait image of Usagi provides information on the mindset of Usagi. Reviewers of the game celebrated the demands on the player to think about he consequence of their actions. In addition the game requires certain etiquette to be adhered to. Usagi must bow appropriately to others, who are of the same or higher status as himself, who would often pass on information. If Usagi attacks a defenceless creature or an unarmed traveller, he loses all his karma points and he is required to commit hare-kari.
[Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/samurai-warrior-the-battles-of-usagi-yojimbo/
Last accessed: 13/8/2020]

The scenery beautifully detailed, and the game presents sideways scrolling action, with Usagi’s movements on the right of the screen, and the left dedicated to status information. The landscape forms an important is part of the game, with creatures lurking behind rocks or up trees. There are also rivers and chasms, which require skill to jump over safely.

The scoring system is based on karma points: good deeds increase Usagi’s karma points, while bad deeds decrease it. Each interaction with other characters must be considered in relation to karma. results.title_for_label: Samurai Warrior: The Battles of Usagi Yojimbo
results.description:
Samurai Warrior: The Battles of Usagi Yojimbo is based on a successful comic book by Stan Sakai. The hero is an anthropomorphic rabbit named Miyamoto Usagi, living in 17th-century Japan. Usagi is a masterless samurai (a ronin), who wanders the land, occasionally taking up work as a bodyguard.

In this game, you play as Usagi, who sword fights his opponents – bandits and ninjas – who often disguise themselves as harmless villagers or priests. The aim of the game is for Usagi to rescue Lord Noriyuki, a panda who has been captured by Lord Hikiji.

The scenery is beautifully detailed, and the game presents sideways scrolling action, with Usagi’s movements on the right of the screen, and the left dedicated to status information. The landscape forms an important part of the game, with creatures lurking behind rocks or up trees. There are also rivers and chasms, which require skill to jump over safely.

The scoring system is based on karma points: good deeds increase Usagi’s karma points, while bad deeds decrease them. Each interaction with other characters must be considered in relation to karma. A larger portrait image of Usagi provides information on the mindset of Usagi. Reviewers of the game celebrated the demands on the player to think about he consequence of their actions. In addition the game requires certain etiquette to be adhered to. Usagi must bow appropriately to others, who are of the same or higher status as himself, who would often pass on information. If Usagi attacks a defenceless creature or an unarmed traveller, he loses all his karma points and he is required to commit hare kari – ritual suicide.

Our version of the game is playable on the Commodore 64.

[Source: Play It Again website: http://www.ourdigitalheritage.org/archive/playitagain/games/samurai-warrior-the-battles-of-usagi-yojimbo/

Last accessed: 13/8/2020]
